awd_titl_txt: CAREER: New strategy to outsmart antimicrobial resistance: Mastering evolution of beta-lactamases catalytic mechanism through reaction pathways alignment, simulation, and analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Peng Tao of Southern Methodist University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop new computational methods to model and predict the evolution of beta-lactamase catalytic mechanisms that lead to dangerous antibiotic resistant strains. How proteins are evolved is a vital question to answer for all living systems on earth. Previous studies focusing on protein sequences and structures provided great insight into protein evolution. However, there is a lack of understanding about functional mechanisms for proteins, especially for enzymes. This prevents deeper understanding of protein evolution. To meet this challenge, Professor Tao and his research group are developing an advanced theoretical framework and computational techniques to connect the evolution of enzyme sequences and structure to the evolution of their functions, catalytic activity, and mechanisms. They focus on beta-lactamases as enzymes that hydrolyze beta-lactam antibiotics and serve as one main cause of antimicrobial resistance. This work will provide fundamental understanding about the evolution of beta-lactamases' catalytic mechanisms, and could help develop a new generation of antibiotics with low resistance. The award also supports the development of educational materials to boost basic science education and outreach on social media. These freely accessible materials will benefit and shape the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers from economically disadvantaged student populations.

The project focuses on developing a theoretical framework to describe enzymatic mechanism landscapes, which are defined as the structural analysis of aligned reaction pathways of evolutionarily related enzymes using statistical and machine-learning methods. This theoretical framework is helping to predict how new mutations in enzymes could lead to changes in catalytic mechanisms and activities. New computational methods are being developed by Professor Tao and his research group to explore enzyme structure-function relations and provide the missing connection between the evolution of protein structure and the variations in enzyme mechanism that are less amenable to experiment. They are also developing online-based chemistry education channels and outreach platforms to enhance general chemistry education through collaboration with teachers from other schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The research conducted under this project has achieved advancements in developing machine-learning-based computational methods for understanding the evolution of enzyme catalysis, particularly focusing on β-lactamases and their role in antibiotic resistance.

 

A Proof-of-Concept

We, the research group led by the PI, have elucidated enzymatic reaction mechanisms using advanced computational and machine-learning approaches. Catalytic pathways of TEM-1, a Class A β-lactamase, were calculated using hybrid quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) methods within the chain-of-states framework. This method describes a chemical reaction from reactants to products through a series of intermediate structures along the minimum energy pathway (MEP). Regression models, including Support Vector Regression (SVR), Gaussian Process Regression (GPR), and Kernel Ridge Regression (KRR), were implemented to quantify energetic contributions of individual chemical events during catalysis. This approach, applied to 18 simulated catalytic pathways of TEM-1, identified key energetic events such as proton transfers involving Lys73 and Ser130 and their roles in pathway viability.

 

Improved Model with One Enzyme Against Two Ligands

Hydrolysis mechanisms of two β-lactam-based antibiotics, ampicillin and cefalexin, catalyzed by another Class A β-lactamase, TOHO-1 (also known as CTX-M-44), were delineated using the QM/MM method. These two antibiotics were used to illustrate the improved catalytic efficiency of TOHO-1 compared to TEM-1. We developed a QM/MM computational workflow that achieves fast sampling of QM/MM MEPs for enzyme catalysis. A Boltzmann-weighted Cumulative Integrated Gradients (BCIG) approach was applied to derive mechanistic insights into machine learning (ML) models. Additionally, a feed-forward neural network employing the "Deep-and-Wide" Neural Network (DaWNN) architecture was developed for modeling QM/MM MEPs.

We also modeled the deacylation reaction of imipenem (IPM) by GES-5 carbapenemase (GES) to reveal the mechanistic factors that facilitate carbapenem resistance. QM/MM calculations were applied to sample the GES/IPM deacylation barriers on the MEPs. We constructed graph representations of the GES/IPM active site. An edge-conditioned graph convolutional neural network (ECGCNN) was trained on the acyl-enzyme conformational graphs to learn the underlying correlations between GES/IPM conformations and the deacylation barriers. A perturbative approach was proposed to interpret the latent representations from the graph-learning (GL) model and extract essential mechanistic understanding at the atomistic level.

 

Mechanism Behind "Superbugs"

Superbugs are strains of bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites that have developed resistance to multiple types of antibiotics or other antimicrobial drugs. We identified two representative metallo-β-lactamases (MBLs), New Delhi metallo-β-lactamase 1 (NDM-1) and Verona integron-encoded MBL 2 (VIM-2), both associated with superbugs, to investigate catalytic mechanisms of MBLs against the antibiotic cefiderocol. Approved in 2019, cefiderocol is one of the most recently U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-approved β-lactam-based antibiotics. Its first cases of antibiotic resistance were reported in 2021. Reaction pathway models using the chain-of-states framework and QM/MM methods were developed to reveal potential catalytic mechanisms of NDM-1 and VIM-2 against cefiderocol.

 

Dynamics of Related Protein Evolution

We extended the machine-learning analysis approach for single-protein functional state recognition to multiple evolutionarily related proteins. Four evolutionarily related proteins, including TEM-1 and TOHO-1 as Class A β-lactamases, penicillin-binding protein A (PBP-A), and DD-transpeptidase as two PBPs, were subjected to molecular dynamics simulations and machine-learning-based analyses to characterize their dynamical behaviors. Penicillin G served as a common ligand for these four proteins of interest. Hidden Markov Models (HMM) and transition path theory (TPT) were applied to identify key dynamical properties related to potential evolutionary correlations among these four proteins. Dynamic analyses of overall structures, the active sites with penicillin G, and three catalytically important residues commonly shared by all four proteins revealed unexpected cross-similarities between Class A β-lactamases and PBPs.

 

Interdisciplinary Collaboration

We collaborated with Dr. Timothy Palzkill from the Baylor College of Medicine to integrate both experimental and computational methods to elucidate the catalysis of serine β-lactamases. Dr. Palzkill, an expert in serine β-lactamase structures and catalysis, contributed to studies on two enzymes, OXA-48 and OXA-163, members of carbapenem-hydrolyzing Class D β-lactamases (CHDLs). Extensive molecular dynamics simulations of OXA-48 and OXA-163 bound to imipenem and meropenem were carried out to explore their binding interactions and catalytic mechanisms.

 

Education

The PI has developed an online computational and chemistry educational channel featuring videos and demonstrations aimed at enhancing teaching effectiveness, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic. Undergraduate student Trevor Heinzmann, supported by the grant, generated quantum chemistry reaction pathways using the intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) method and created educational videos illustrating organic reaction mechanisms. The PI's group also participated in organizing the first DFW Regional Theoretical Chemistry Research Meeting in January 2019. Furthermore, a new graduate course, CHEM 6348 Statistical Molecular Thermodynamics, was developed with support from this research grant. These efforts underscore the PI's commitment to integrating research, education, and outreach.


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Peng Tao

  • Acylation reaction against Ampicillin and Cefalexin catalyzed by TOHO-1 β-lactamase. (I) Catalytic Mechanisms of Acylation; (II) Active site conformations of reactant states; (III) Energy profiles and the partial charges of key atoms along the acylation reaction pathways.

  • TEM-1 as Serine based beta-Lactamase: Acylation Reaction with Benzylpenicillin and Machine Learning Insights.     Peng Tao
    Creative Commons
    Peng Tao
    Machine Learning Models for TEM-1 Acylation Mechanism with Benzylpenicillin
  • Mechanistic Insights into the deacylation reaction of Imipenem (IPM) by GES-5 carbapenemases based on the Edge-conditioned graph convolutional neural network (ECGCNN) model. (I) Mechanism; (II) Barrier; (III) ECGCNN Architecture; (IV) Latent vector evaluation; (V) Cluster analysis of acyl-enzyme.
    Peng Tao
    Creative Commons
    Peng Tao
    Graph-Learning Guided Mechanistic Insights into Imipenem Hydrolysis in GES Carbapenemases

(I) Acylation Mechanism; (II) Selected features, 2D representation, and the architecture of BCIG; (III) Reaction barriers; (IV) Prediction of BCIG model; (V) Key distances and partial charges.
    Peng Tao
    Creative Commons
    Peng Tao
    Explainable Machine Learning Models for Acylation Mechanism of TOHO-1 against Ampicillin and Cefalexin
  • Unveiling Structural Features Regulating Carbapenems Deacylation in KPC-2 Through Interpretable Machine Learning. (I) Active site configurations; (II) Orientations of key function group; (III) Features selection; (IV) Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) values; (V) Key features distribution.
    Peng Tao

    Peng Tao

The research conducted under this project has achieved advancements in developing machine-learning-based computational methods for understanding the evolution of enzyme catalysis, particularly focusing on -lactamases and their role in antibiotic resistance.





A Proof-of-Concept


We, the research group led by the PI, have elucidated enzymatic reaction mechanisms using advanced computational and machine-learning approaches. Catalytic pathways of TEM-1, a Class A -lactamase, were calculated using hybrid quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) methods within the chain-of-states framework. This method describes a chemical reaction from reactants to products through a series of intermediate structures along the minimum energy pathway (MEP). Regression models, including Support Vector Regression (SVR), Gaussian Process Regression (GPR), and Kernel Ridge Regression (KRR), were implemented to quantify energetic contributions of individual chemical events during catalysis. This approach, applied to 18 simulated catalytic pathways of TEM-1, identified key energetic events such as proton transfers involving Lys73 and Ser130 and their roles in pathway viability.

Hydrolysis mechanisms of two -lactam-based antibiotics, ampicillin and cefalexin, catalyzed by another Class A -lactamase, TOHO-1 (also known as CTX-M-44), were delineated using the QM/MM method. Additionally, a feed-forward neural network employing the "Deep-and-Wide" Neural Network (DaWNN) architecture was developed for modeling QM/MM MEPs.


We also modeled the deacylation reaction of imipenem (IPM) by GES-5 carbapenemase (GES) to reveal the mechanistic factors that facilitate carbapenem resistance.
